page.name: Strength
page.content:
Strength

Strength measures bodily power, athletic training, and raw physical power.

Ability Checks
Use general ability checks for situations like:

  • An attempt to lift a very heavy object.
  • Trying to push open a stuck door.
  • Attempting to break free from bonds.
  • Carrying something a long way.
  • Trying to hold on to a ledge or rope.

Attack & Damage Rolls
The Strength modifier is added to attack and damage rolls for:

  • Melee Attacks
  • Ranged Attacks with Thrown Weapons

Alternate Skills
Some skills you can pair with this ability are:

  • Animal Handling. Attempting to use brute force to subdue an animal.
  • Intimidation. Trying to look scary versus trying to threaten someone with words.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 175

page.name: Athletics
page.content:
Athletics

General athletic prowess when running, jumping, swimming, and climbing.

Skill Checks
Use athletics skill checks for situations like:

  • Attemping to climb a cliff or rope.
  • Trying to jump very high or far.
  • Swimming against a strong current.

Alternate Abilities
Abilities that can be paired with this skill are:

  • Constitution. Running long distance are as much about constitution as strength.
  • Dexterity. Some feats are more about dexterity, but see Acrobatics first.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 175

page.name: Dexterity
page.content:
Dexterity

Dexterity measures agility, reflexes, and balance.

Ability Checks
Use general ability checks for situations like:

  • Picking a lock or disabling a trap.
  • Tie up a prisoner with some rope.
  • Wriggle free after being tied up.
  • Craft a small or detailed object.

Initiative is a general dexterity check.

Attack & Damage Rolls
The Dexterity modifier is added to attack and damage rolls for:

  • Ranged Attacks
  • Melee Attacks with Finesse Weapons

Alternate Skills
Some skills you can pair with this ability are:

  • Athletics. Some feats of athleticism might be better suited to dexterity than strength.
  • Performance. Playing an instrument may be a better ability to use than charisma.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 176

page.name: Acrobatics
page.content:
Acrobatics

Acrobatics measures the ability to maintain balance, tumble, and perform tricks in the air.

Skill Checks
Use skill checks for situations like:

  • Walk across a tightrope.
  • Maintain balance on a rocking ship.
  • Parkour down a cluttered alley.

Alternate Abilities
Abilities that can be paired with this skill are:

  • N/A

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 176

page.name: Armor Class
page.content:
Armor Class

A creature’s natural armor class is how hard they are to hit when not wearing armor.

Natural AC = 10 + Dexterity Modifier

Wearing Armor
Wearing armor replaces a creature’s natural AC with that of the armor they are wearing.

Armor Type AC
Padded L 11 + DEX
Leather L 11 + DEX
Studded L 12 + DEX
Hide M 12 + DEX (max 2)
Chain Shirt M 13 + DEX (max 2)
Scale Mail M 14 + DEX (max 2)
Breastplate M 14 + DEX (max 2)
Half Plate M 15 + DEX (max 2)

Characters wearing heavy armor do not add their DEX modifier to their AC.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 145, 177

page.name: Hiding
page.content:
Hiding

Contest between hider & active searcher.

Hider (Stealth) v. Searcher (Perception)

  • DM decides when hiding is possible.
  • Cannot hide if clearly visible.
  • Cannot hide if searcher saw you hide.
  • Invisible creatures can always try.
  • Sound & tracks can give them away.
  • Ends if discovered or stop hiding.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 177

page.name: Advantage
page.content:
Advantage
Advantage Roll 2d20 and take the higher of the two rolls.
Disdvantage Roll 2d20 and take the lower of the two rolls.

Rules

  • A player cannot have double advantage or disadvantage. They do not stack.
  • A player with advantage & disadvantage gets neither. It is straight roll.
  • A feat or feature that allows a player to roll again, they choose which die.

Sources: Player’s Handbook, p. 173

Conditions

A creature affected by a condition

  • A condition lasts until it is countered or
  • when the duration of the effect causing the condition has expired.

page.name: Blinded
page.content:
Blinded

A blinded creature cannot see and:

  • checks based on sight fail,
  • attacks against it have advantage,
  • its attacks have disadvantage,

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Deafened
page.content:
Deafened

A deafened creature cannot hear and:

  • checks based on hearing fail.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Exhaustion
page.content:
Exhaustion

An exhausted creature has:

Level Effect
1 Disadvantage on ability checks
2 Speed halved
3 Disadvantage on attacks & saves
4 Hit point maximum halved
5 Speed reduced to 0
6 Death
  • Additional points increase the level.
  • Suffer effects of current & lower levels.
  • Ends if level is reduced below level 1.
  • Long rest lowers level w/ food & drink.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Frightened
page.content:
Frightened

A frightened creature:

  • has disadvantage on checks & attacks while source of fear is in sight.
  • Can’t move closer to source of fear.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Grappled
page.content:
Grappled

A grappled creature:

  • has a speed of 0,
  • cannot benefit from bonus to speed,

The condition is removed if the:

  • grappler releases the creature,
  • creature is forced out of reach.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Incapacitated
page.content:
Incapacitated

An incapacitated creature:

  • cannot take actions or reactions.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 290

page.name: Invisible
page.content:
Invisible

An invisible creature:

  • is impossible to see without magic,
  • is heavily obscured when hiding,
  • can be detected by noise & tracks,
  • has advantage on attacks,

Attacks against have disadvantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Paralyzed
page.content:
Paralyzed

A paralyzed creature:

  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws.

Attacks against have advantage and hits within 5’ are critical hits.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Petrified
page.content:
Petrified

A petrified creature:

  • is transformed into a solid substance,
  • its mundane items are transformed too,
  • has it its weight increase by ten,
  • stops aging,
  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws,
  • has resistance to all damage,
  • is immune to poison and disease, but current poison or disease is suspended

Attacks against have advantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 291

page.name: Poisoned
page.content:
Poisoned

A poisoned creature:

  • has disadvantage on attacks & checks.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Prone
page.content:
Prone

A prone creature:

  • can only crawl, unless it stands up,
  • has disadvantage on attacks,

Attacks against have advantage and hits within 5’ are critical hits.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Restrained
page.content:
Restrained

A restrained creature:

  • has a speed of 0,
  • cannot benefit from bonus to speed,
  • has disadvantage on attacks,
  • has disadvantage on dex saves.

Attack against have advantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Stunned
page.content:
Stunned

A stunned creature:

  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • can only speak falteringly,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws,

Attack against have advantage.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292

page.name: Unconcious
page.content:
Unconcious

An unconcious creature:

  • is incapacitated & can’t move or speak,
  • drops what it is holding and falls prone,
  • fails strength & dexterity saving throws,

Attacks against have advantage and hits within 5’ are critical hits.

Source: Player’s Handbook, p. 292
